title: Will negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) be completed before 1 January 2016?
preds: 11 hours to go and nothing seems to  be imminent.

Joint Statement on the RCEP Negotiations
ASEAN
22 November 2015 "We instruct our Ministers and negotiators to further intensify their efforts and we look forward to the conclusion of the RCEP negotiations in 2016, contributing  significantly to regional and global economic integration, providing for equitable economic development, and strengthening economic cooperation." http://www.asean.org/storage/2015/12/RCEP-Leaders-Joint-Statement_22-Nov-2015_FINAL.pdf
There are four more rounds scheduled and they are all in 2016.
As of December 17th this looks like cheap scoring.. ;-)
Recent news reports offer little optimism that this trade agreement will be ratified within the timeframe outlined in this question.
No news is not good news for completion. Affirming prior prediction.

New Year's resolutions for RCEP negotiators
Nikkei Asian Review
December 8, 2015 "The recent decision by the governments negotiating the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership to postpone their target date for an agreement was inevitable, given their lack of progress. But the delay of a year, to the end of 2016, may be a blessing in disguise. It gives the negotiators more time to realign their goals in the new year and push for a more ambitious pact." http://asia.nikkei.com/Viewpoints/Viewpoints/New-Year-s-resolutions-for-RCEP-negotiators

Nov 22's RCEP Joint Statement already commented they continue the negotiation in 2016. Quoted below: 5. We instruct our Ministers and negotiators to further intensify their efforts and we look forward to the conclusion of the RCEP negotiations in 2016, contributing significantly to regional and global economic integration, providing for equitable economic development, and strengthening economic cooperation

According to this: "International Trade and Industry Minister Datuk Seri Mustapa Mohamed said the pressure to achieve progress in the RCEP was building up given the fact that negotiations for the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement (TPPA) was concluded last month. "There is a lot of pressure to achieve progress in RCEP given as China is not in the TPPA. It is important to have China in any major trade deal. "Asean leaders will convene in Laos for the Asean Economic Ministers' Meeting in March 2016 to discuss the RCEP's progress," he told a press conference here today. The RCEP is a proposed free trade agreement (FTAs) between the 10 member states of Asean and the six states with which Asean has existing FTAs namely Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea and New Zealand. Its conclusion, expected next year, would contribute significantly to regional and global economic integration, provide for equitable economic development and strengthen economic cooperation. — Bernama" http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1617533 That article comes directly from the ARIC site. 
https://aric.adb.org/fta/regional-comprehensive-economic-partnership

My latest forecast is based on a news article found by Khalid.  I repeat it here: http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/rcep-negotiations-still/2283112.html A delay until 2016 was announce on November 22, 2015.

They just held the 10th round of negotiations in October. Positive outlook. http://www.tax-news.com/news/ASEAN_Reinforces_Commitment_to_RCEP____69829.html http://dfat.gov.au/trade/agreements/rcep/pages/regional-comprehensive-economic-partnership.aspx

Rodney (Admins: to whom I cannot comment: there is no reply button) found this interesting link: http://www.tax-news.com/news/ASEAN_Reinforces_Commitment_to_RCEP____69829.html.  I agree that they would _like_ to complete this according to 2015 schedule, however there are some mitigating circumstances.  First, TPP was putting pressure on ASEAN to complete this agreement.  But, within TPP member countries, TPP seems to be dead in the water.  Additionally, meeting locations have been released for RCEP next year.  (http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms  This link is stale relative to Rodney's, but still ...)  I have increased my probability because I think the RCEP negotiators are watching the reception TPP is going to receive.

ASEAN Reinforces Commitment to RCEP
Tax-News
01 December 2015 "The leaders of the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) looked forward to the early conclusion of negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade treaty in a statement following their meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on November 21. It was originally intended that negotiations on the proposed RCEP would be concluded by the end of this year. ... However, until August this year, it had been difficult for the countries to reach a consensus over further cuts to import tariffs, particularly in relation to sensitive products. It is believed that this issue has now been largely overcome, with duties set to be eliminated on 65 percent of tariff lines immediately, rising to 80 percent of tariff lines in 10 years. The leaders' statement confirmed that, "following this breakthrough, substantive negotiations in the core areas have intensified." They have asked negotiators to further reinforce their efforts to reach an agreement." http://www.tax-news.com/news/ASEAN_Reinforces_Commitment_to_RCEP____69829.html
Khalid's comment is the clincher --> https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/47206 It was a week ago (must have missed it in the feed) -- h/t to Dima K for including a link to it in the rationale.

http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-11/22/c_134842294.htm Enhanced efforts were called for to conclude the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) talks next year at the ongoing 27th ASEAN leaders' summit and related meetings. "Substantial progress" had been made. . .  Launched in November 2012, the RCEP talks involved 10 ASEAN member states and six dialogue partners - China, Japan, South Korea, Australia, New Zealand and India - with an aim to facilitate expansion of regional trade and investment and were scheduled for completion in 2015. . . . 10 rounds of negotiations had been completed in addition to four ministerial-level meetings. "However, considering the challenges faced and value of constructive engagements, more time was needed to conclude the negotiations, the statement said. "We request our negotiators to intensify efforts to conclude and achieve a mutually beneficially and high-quality agreement in 2016."
. . . 
Under the theme "Our People, Our Community, Our Vision," the two-day summit issued the 2015 Kuala Lumpur Declaration on the Establishment of the ASEAN Community, signaling the formal creation the community by Dec. 31 this year.

http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/rcep-negotiations-still/2283112.html I was waiting for the ASEAN summit in Malaysia, where the results of the October RCEP discussions were to be presented. I thought there was a chance that a partial agreement would be signed off while negotiations on the 10-15% remaining items would continue in a second phase.  However, the summit concluded yesterday, and it was announced that negotiations will continue next year.

RCEP talks: India submits first round of offers on goods
The Hindu Business Line
November 19, 2015 "India has finally submitted its first round of detailed offers to dismantle tariffs on goods as part of the ambitious Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) being negotiated between 16 countries. The move comes ahead of the India-ASEAN Summit next week, where discussions on fast-tracking the negotiations are likely to take place. ... The next round of negotiations is likely in February, when the existing offers and the scope to improve them will be discussed." http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/rcep-talks-india-submits-first-round-of-offers-on-goods/article7896740.ece
There are probably some edge cases where this might occur.  Still don't think it's very probable.
Nothing is tied up yet and a month and 10 days won't solve the India-Singapore block nor the rest.
http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/china-to-work-with-others-to-finalise-16-nation-trade-pact-early-xi Mid-article, Malaysian Prime Minister confirms they are now aiming for 2016.

Until TPP presents a more clearer picture to ASEAN countries China will speculate for some time. China, once closer to completion of building land on South China Sea they will not speed up the process. The negotiations will speed up once TPP is closer to action.

TPP has not been ratified yet.  In one sense, this is about China, South Korea and India playing catch-up with TPP.  However, now that the text of TPP has been released, and those outside of the negotiation teams have seen it, there will be push-back on that treaty.  Given the time until question expiration it is unlikely any progress will be made on this RCEP until TPP is more in focus.
Not enough time, not enough will.

No clarity or agreement has been achieved yet on what tariffs each country will liberalise, India and Indonesia lagging in proposals. This will take time to work out and is not feasible before end of this year, also because the next RCEP round will only be in February,
Does not make any sense for the parties to complete the negotiations before that date.
No way in 2 months. Almost makes me think that putting January 1st 2016 was a mistake.
The crowd prediction hasn't changed with more forecasters, so I'm going to lower my forecast.
correcting autofill probability value of last prediction

Among other remaining issues, India and Indonesia failed to make offers for tariff liberalization in Busan. Next round of talks agreed to take place in Feb, host country unannounced according to ET. India is a notoriously difficult partner with which to reach trade agreements (WTO, Israel-India FTA etc). 
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms
http://www.livemint.com/Politics/5hNv64auvYDNYBQ31uGSoM/India-may-provide-most-favoured-status-to-RCEP-investors.html
not likely, clock wins this game

I agree with Shador13 that the next round of negotiations is in February 2016.  Clearly, we will need at least a round or two more to start hammering out a rough agreement, from what I have read so far.  Yes, we had the trilateral summit, but all it promises is that progress will be made on this issue.  Not resolution.  Lots of talk about favorable inclination, but no agreement yet.  
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership#Round_10:_October_2015_in_South_Korea

A recent white paper released in July by China stated that "the traditional mentality that land outweighs sea must be abandoned." In other words, a more confrontational stance towards countries who are part of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) negotiations would make it harder to pass by the end of the year (http://thediplomat.com/2015/06/chinas-white-paper-implications-for-southeast-asia/) .
Furthermore, an article by the Economist dated October 3, 2015, stated the RCEP is due in 2016 (http://www.economist.com/sites/default/files/20151003_world_econ.pdf).
With the exercising of the United States' Freedom of Navigation Operation (FONOP) last week, China has more pressing issues on its table.
Too many moving parts to be completed that quickly.
Too soon, I don't think so.
Too complicated; an election year to boot; no way this gets done soon or even at all.

It will be completed, probably with some adjustments because of the following possibilities: China may require job security for its people who may lose manufacturing jobs to countries that pay lower salaries.
Singapore may require environmental controls for work that is exported.
Australia may require that a system of labor relations are in place for products being manufactured overseas.

Nice quick comparison link here on RCEP vs. TPP:
http://www.todayonline.com/world/comparing-rcep-tpp?page=1
time will not permit the completion of negotiations.
Everybody else thinks this event is highly unlikely. The crowd is swaying my opinion. I'm lowering prediction.

Surely not, next rounds of negotiaition are planned to be made in 2016:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership#Round_10:_October_2015_in_South_Korea it looks like there are still many things to dispute.
They just reopened discussions. These things take time
Negotiations will not be completed before Jan 1, 2016; scheduled negotiation rounds are scheduled beyond this date.
Politics nether party will want to be seen as exporting jobs.
Given international tensions over FTA's negotiations may be intentionally delayed to ensure a more receptive response from the electorates.

Really? This timeline is way too short.
In the ninth round of negotiations held in August this year, "The Working Group on Electronic Commerce met for the first time. Discussions on telecommunications and financial services commenced and the first meeting of these Sub-Working Groups will commence at the next round (Korea 12-16 October)."
http://dfat.gov.au/trade/agreements/rcep/pages/regional-comprehensive-economic-partnership.aspx Although, like all other FTA negotiations, there isn't much information, so we don't really know how quickly agreements are reached but judging from what has been commenced/discussed over the numerous rounds of negotiations, decisions don't seem to be reached quickly. They should've made the question longer or or included multiple choices further into the future.
Unlikely within the time frame, especially while ratification of the TPP is pending.
A deadline on this agreement serves no purpose for these negotiators, and as long as China keeps on building land to claim it, there will be no proress.

Deadlines are often artificial in nature. Missing them has no real consequence when they are artificial. Even when missing one does result in negative consequences for others, many decision makers  miss them anyway.
Ha!  Not as long as China continues to build land and put runways on it.  Also, this will occur too soon after the most recent plenum in China.
Too much turmoil in world for any agreements/

In light of this article:
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms And the empty promises here:
http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2015/10/30/0200000000AEN20151030005500320.html My thought is that this will easily go past Jan 1 2016.
I am changing my forecast because the group consensus is so low.

http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms
"NEW DELHI: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), an Asia-Pacific free-trade grouping that includes India, is set to miss its deadline of 2015 even as pressure mounts on the bloc to reach an agreement following the 12-country Trans-Pacific Partnership sealed by developed nations. One cause for the delay is India and Indonesia failing to make offers for tariff liberalisation at talks held in Busan, South Korea, last week.  "Our stakeholder consultations went on till the first week of October and we are still getting comments from them after which we will finalise the offers," an official said, explaining the delay.  Of the 16 members of the RCEP, 14 made their offers of tariff cuts.  "The talks will spill over to next year. It's been decided that the next round of negotiations will be held in February but who would host it is not yet clear. Australia plans to host the April round and New Zealand the one in June," the official added. "
Revising downwards after learning some trivialities.
Following Clinton, great link and analysis.

This is the kind of question where if somebody was sufficiently motivated, they could just simply call the head guy in Malaysia and ask, "Yo, buddy, what's up with India and Indonesia? Can you sign it without their schedules?"
Initial forecast base rate based on the crowd and info review.

Believing this at face value: http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms and also this http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/743136/full-steam-ahead-for-rcep-trade-deal - which states that 15% of items still need further talks and assuming that will be the Feb meeting referred.

The TPP has not been completed. There remains ratification risk in the US, due to presidential campaign politics and poorly functioning legislature. That diminishes pressure on the alternative  India and China continue to work at cross purposes on multiple dimensions - delay is fallout
Offsetting pressure from E.U., U.S. and Trade Partners involved in the negotiations with close ties to both will delay the completion of the RCEP

At the ASEAN Summit in 2011, the group adopted the Framework for Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership.  Under “process,” the Framework states:  “The agreement can be accomplished in a sequential manner or single undertaking or through any other agreed modality.”  http://www.asean.org/news/item/asean-framework-for-regional-comprehensive-economic-partnership The Framework tells us the agreement may be implemented in phases.  The following article (posted by morrell) supports this and expands upon it.  
“Under the agreed first step in RCEP trade liberalisation, tariffs covering 65 per of trade will be immediately cut to zero following the pact's implementation.  In the next phase, tariffs on another 20 per cent of trade in goods will be gradually reduced to zero within 10 years, while import duties for the remaining 15 per cent will remain in place or be gradually reduced to 5-10 per cent, as those products comprise the list of sensitive goods drawn up by member states.” http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/RCEP-members-agree-to-eliminate-tariffs-on-65-of-t-30271561.html Based on this information, I assume what the question means is whether the Phase 1 of the agreement will be implemented before the end of the year.  It does not make any sense for the question to refer to more than that because clearly more than that will not happen. The ASEAN Summit is set for November 18-22 and I expect this will be on the agenda for a vote.   I am also making an assumption about the meetings set for 2016.  For RCEP, implementation is not finalization.  It begins a process.  The scheduling of meetings is not an admission that they can’t get the deal finished, although that may happen.   RCEP seems to have more flexibility built into it for the countries involved than trade agreements other questions have covered.    They have chosen to address the easier issues first and then move on to the more difficult ones instead of creating an all-encompassing agreement from the start.

Searching within various countries, have become more convinced that no agreement has yet been reached.
http://pulsenews.co.kr/view.php/view.php?no=1030339&year=2015
http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22legislation%2Fems%2Fr5550_ems_2c6c6336-590f-4596-abd1-90305b256f5b%22
Following Malcmur, but I'm less afraid of Brier scoring. Good link, thank you.

Trade deals take a long time and there is little indication that a 2015 deadline will be met.  Nothing in mid-October suggests that there is any real commitment to a 2015 end date with most saying they "aim to conclude" by that time.  Also the next meeting after October 2015 isn't until early 2016.
No deal from the earlier meeting, next meeting not scheduled till feb 2016
Reducing due to ambiguity in Q wording, not sure if signing the agreement will resolve the question. Negotiations likely to continue into 2016 even if the agreement will be signed in November.
Haven't looked into this too much, but it seems like the crowd may be overconfident.

It will not be as comprehensive as originally intended. A frame work of sorts will be agreed upon. 
There is lot of distrust among these countries and coming to a consensus is not easy.

I'm decreasing my initial forecast of 20% made just yesterday because the consensus is so much lower - 2% at the moment.  If one goes by the exact wording of this question, the negotiations are unlikely to be completed by the end of this year unless a strong sense of urgency impels all participants. However, there have also been reports of an agreement being signed at the ASEAN summit next month (see several references in earlier comments). This would presumably cover the 65% or 8-9,000 goods that have been agreed upon. It seems also to have been agreed that another 20% would have their tariffs gradually cut to zero over a ten year period, but that negotiations would continue for the remaining 15%. We may thus have a situation where an "RCEP" exists but  which isn't as comprehensive as originally intended. How does this question resolve if an RCEP is signed but negotiations continue for an RCEP Plus? If one is being literal, the resolution will be "no", but I'm not going to zero yet. We may have to wait till the ASEAN summit to get clarity, unless GJ's Admin issues some guidance earlier.
People tend to fall into planning fallacies.

The official communique from the August meetings says:
"The Ministers emphasised that the RCEP Trade Negotiating Committee should expedite the negotiations with a view to substantially concluding the negotiations by the end of 2015 with the remaining technical issues to be resolved as soon as possible in 2016."
http://www.asean.org/images/2015/August/47th-aem/10%20-%20JMS%20RCEP%203%20MM%20-%20Final%2020150824rev.pdf

The regional and global view of risks, respective mitigation and economic capability to ;project power,attract partnership, deter instigators and sustain security - will determine what committed positions will fit a constantly changing global context.  Both short term and long term strategic thinking will also influence perception of strength from a unified standpoint. The traditional nature of this region makes me inclined to independence of their decision making and outcomes of individual decisions. January is too close but, I only see a delay in the decisions but an eventual agreement in some form.

http://www.livemint.com/Politics/5buPF8FCjkl81F85hVNh2J/India-told-to-submit-list-of-commodities-to-RCEP-members-by.html `India must submit a list of its commodities for tariff reduction to other members of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), latest by 15 November, so that they can start analysing offers. India and Indonesia had failed to submit their proposals for tariff cuts at the just concluded RCEP negotiations at Busan, South Korea. “Most countries have exchanged the offers list now. We have been given time till 15 November. Once we exchange the offer via email, every other country can start analysing the offers,” a government official said, speaking under condition of anonymity.` I don't expect a hurried India to come to the rescue of a treaty China holds dear.
This closes in 2 months!  (I was thinking a year and 2 months.)  No way will this resolve in 2 months.  No wonder so many people have forecast 0.  I'm going there, too.

http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/articleshow/49499225.cms? " . . . RCEP . . .  is set to miss its deadline of 2015 even as pressure mounts on the bloc to reach an agreement following the 12-country Trans-Pacific Partnership sealed by developed nations. One cause for the delay is India and Indonesia failing to make offers for tariff liberalisation at talks held in Busan, South Korea, last week. "Our stakeholder consultations went on till the first week of October and we are still getting comments from them after which we will finalise the offers," an official said, explaining the delay.  Of the 16 members of the RCEP, 14 made their offers of tariff cuts.  "The talks will spill over to next year. It's been decided that the next round of negotiations will be held in February but who would host it is not yet clear. Australia plans to host the April round and New Zealand the one in June," the official added.  "Sources said the delay could also be due to India reconsidering an offer it planned to make to China, Australia and New Zealand to remove duties on 42.5 per cent of the items traded with each of the countries.  "The pressure to conclude the RCEP pact is greater following the US-led TPP deal.  Seven countries common to both trading blocs - Australia, Brunei, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore and Vietnam - are pushing for an accord on RCEP to be reached in the same manner as the TPP.  "Another reason for the delay is the emergence of differences over how to certify rules of origin, which determine the national source of a product and the associated benefits and duties.  While Australia and New Zealand want self-certification by exporters, others including India are in favour of third-party validation. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  India held up the TFA for years.  3 rounds of negotiations are planned; if they were close, they'd not be planning so many more rounds.  These trade deals take a long, long time.
China will dictate or hinder the progress
His goal is to add chaos to anything formal, normal or expected. He wants to be a wild card.
He will not do anything to conform.
nothing will get done in next few months because of congress

Lowering because everyone has gone so hard over to 0.  
I hate going to one end or the other on so little/poor info.

China-backed trade pact playing catch-up after U.S.-led TPP deal
Reuters
Oct 10, 2015 "Left outside the U.S.-backed Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact struck last week, China and India approach this week's talks for a huge Asia-wide equivalent with fresh urgency, lest competitor nations steal a march on export access." ... "Member countries will be under pressure to fast-track negotiations for RCEP," said a senior official in India, which is keen to avoid being excluded from major trade accords." ... "It's not that there is a competition between the RCEP and the TPP, but overall, because of the pressure put on by the TPP, there's hope for a faster end to negotiations for more liberalized trade in the region," Tu (Xinquan) said.The 16 RCEP countries will present their offers for market opening when they meet in Busan in South Korea on Monday, with an aim to make "best efforts" towards reaching agreement by year-end, a South Korean official close to the negotiations said." http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/11/us-trade-tpp-rcep-idUSKCN0S500220151011

There seem to be contradictory reports about the RCEP; different articles seem to suggest that it will be delayed into the next year or signed in late November at the ASEAN summit.  I don't understand why the crowd is so confident that the deal won't go through; it still seems possible that a deal will be signed that will count for the GJP's purposes.  In the absence of solid evidence, I am going to go with my default 20% estimate (increased for gaming).

This update answers a few questions.  
India and Indonesia failed to submit commodity lists at the October Busan SK sessions.  India and Indonesia will not be allowed in the negotiations to view other members commodity offers untill their specific commodity lists are submitted.  India must submit a list by Nov. 15th. Once all lists are received all countries will have access to the lists and are free to analyze and negotiate changes with other members.  This is where the additional scheduled negotiating rounds, scheduled for 2016, are involved.
...However, there are general agreements that have already been agreed to, but not at detail level. If these count as an agreement, they were agreed before this IFP/Question opened.  Going with the assumption that a fuller agreement is required - which will not happen before 2016.
Update: http://www.livemint.com/Politics/5buPF8FCjkl81F85hVNh2J/India-told-to-submit-list-of-commodities-to-RCEP-members-by.html Looks like there a conflicting reports from different countries.
Indiatimes indicates no deal in 2015.

Feb.......TBD
April......Australia
June......New Zealand
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms Bangkokpost reports a signable agreement is already complete:
http://m.bangkokpost.com/business/743136?refer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F
Expected to be signed during the Asean summit in Kuala Lumpur, November 18-22. http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/RCEP-members-agree-to-eliminate-tariffs-on-65-of-t-30271561.html

This question is another example of how hard it is to frame a question..........especially if there is a competition involved (GJP). What does completed mean?  So, I might be going out on a limb a bit. As several members have pointed out, there seems to be RCEP consensus on about 65% of goods and a long-term amorphous plan for dealing with the other goods and services that are "sensitive" to particular countries. HOWEVER, the question is not requiring that all goods and services questions be resolved by an agreement. If that standard was applicable, then any new phase of the TPP (or any agreement) would prolong the answer to that question too.  My prediction/interpretation is that there will be a RCEP agreement completed by January 1, 2016....even though it may not cover all goods and services and even though RCEP may have future rounds to deal with sensitive aspects. The RCEP is essentially a means to eliminate (or smooth edges around) the multiple  Free Trade Agreements (FTA) that China has with many countries. Having multiple FTAs is unwieldy. The RCEP ties to set a single framework. The RCEP partners will announce the agreement.......let the GJP arguing/interpretations begin! (All in fun people, all in fun.)
Far as I can tell, they are not nearly far enough along to meet this deadline. There are negotiation sessions on the official schedule into next Spring.

While there are some reports (thanks Khalid & 000, and adding [1]) that the agreement will be presented and signed at the ASEAN meeting in November, there are also reports that India and Indonesia failed to give required input at the meeting earlier this month.  [2,3]  Not sure how likely it is that those two countries will submit info and everyone else be able to consider it in time.  Plus, as others have noted, there are placeholders for future meetings in 2016 already. Not sure I understand resolution criteria adequately - whether agreement needs to be announced or whether it needs to be signed.  Also not sure if it is possible to reach an agreement without the input of some of the countries....I'm thinking no but may be wrong. [1] http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/RCEP-members-agree-to-eliminate-tariffs-on-65-of-t-30271561.html
[2] http://www.livemint.com/Politics/5buPF8FCjkl81F85hVNh2J/India-told-to-submit-list-of-commodities-to-RCEP-members-by.html
[3] http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/rcep-set-to-miss-2015-deadline-talks-to-spill-over-to-next-year/articleshow/49499225.cms
Difficult to get accomplished with the almost all the Presidential candidates against it.
Difficult to get accomplished with the almost all the Presidential candidates against it.

Thanks to 000 for the Bangkok Post link, which is up to date. I'm much more pessimistic, though. http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/743136/full-steam-ahead-for-rcep-trade-deal
"Sixteen members have tentatively agreed to eliminate tariffs on 65% of all goods, amounting to 8,000-9,000 items, under the RCEP plans,,,,,,at the 10th meeting of negotiating teams from Oct 12-16 in Busan, South Korea.......It will be submitted to the Asean Summit next month in Kuala Lumpur....Further talks are needed for... 15% of products which are mostly sensitive items",  So it looks like there is only a partial agreement at the moment.  A couple of older references provide more details. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership
According to wikipedia, there are three more negotiating rounds scheduled, in February and then April 2016. However, this article doesn't seem to have been updated since June. There's also this article from two months ago
http://www.businesstoday.in/current/economy-politics/mega-trade-pact-recp-to-miss-2015-deadline/story/223100.html
"..Ministers emphasised that the RCEP Trade Negotiating Committee should expedite the negotiations with a view to substantially concluding the negotiations by the end of 2015 with the remaining technical issues to be resolved as soon as possible in 2016."  Thus, unless conclusion of TTP negotiations has injected more urgency into the RCEP process, it doesn't look like it'll be done by 01 Jan 2016. Certainly China and India will be pushing for it as they are not in the TPP but there's not much time to agree on the remaining 15% of goods, mostly "sensitive items".

The 10 members of the ASEAN countries, along with China, Japan, South Korea, India Australia and New Zealand are the 16 RCEP member states.   Ten (10) rounds of negotiations (since November 2011) have been completed with the last in this group held on October 12-16, 2015 in South Korea.  Rounds 11, 12 and 13 have been scheduled with the first in an unknown location and the latter two in Australia and New Zealand.   The latter three rounds are scheduled for 2016 and will not meet the January 1, 2016 deadline.
